ygData.msgSnippet: This means that as of the moment of the report, they re overdue for a wake. If you repeat the report, you should see them either wake, or with even larger

This means that as of the moment of the report, they're overdue for a wake.

If you repeat the report, you should see them either wake, or with even
larger negative numbers.

In the defaul HostQueuesFrontier, the waking of snoozed queues occurs inside
the worker threads themselves. So if all worker threads are busy with other
URIs, no queues will be woken until a worker thread actually asks for a new
URI to process. Also, while a job is paused, no wakes will occur. So the
frontier report of a pause HostQueuesFrontier crawl will often show negative
wake times; those are queues that will wake as soon as the crawl is unpaused.

(In the BdbFrontier, a background thread wakes queues, so even a paused
crawl will show queues moving from snoozed to ready in successive frontier
reports. Only if that waking process has broken would you see more than
transitory/momentary negative wake times.)

- Gordon @ IA

Tom Emerson wrote:
> Looking at the frontier report for a long running crawl, I see wake
> times on two of the queues of -3692ms and -3243ms. Is this a display
> problem am I seeing a real overflow going on?
> 
> TIA,
> 
>     -tree
